observations: Input and output grids have the same dimensions.
The top and bottom rows remain unchanged.
The first and last columns remain unchanged.
The central areas are transformed patterns.
Zeroes in the input are generally propagated to adjacent cells in the same pattern region.
Repeating patterns exist within sections bordered by the constant edges.
hypotheses: The central section is a horizontally repeating pattern with zeroed cells affecting adjacent pattern cells.
The central section mirrors the input pattern within a confined area, with a transformation based on whether there is a zero cell nearby.
The central section applies a nearest-neighbor rule to modify the existing non-edge pattern based on the existence of zeroes.

rejected_hypotheses.hypothesis: The central section mirrors the input pattern within a confined area.
rejected_hypotheses.reason: This fails to explain the transformed patterns near the zeroes in example 1 and 2.

rejected_hypotheses.hypothesis: The central section repeats a single pattern based on dimensions of non-zero components.
rejected_hypotheses.reason: This fails when the zero cells are added; the pattern is disrupted significantly, beyond simply a scaled or tiling pattern.

selected_rule: The central section is filled with a modified version of the input pattern and when there is a zero nearby, propagate that to the corresponding pattern cells nearby.
step_plan: Copy the border rows and columns from the input to the output.
For each cell within the central area, copy the corresponding pattern.
When there is a zero nearby, the pattern propagates that to the non-edge section of the output, and copy those patterns into corresponding blocks.
Assign zeroes into the specific regions in patterns with zero cells in the input.
